III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; volunteer,
Section contractors on central registry
Description • (2) A staff member must be of responsible character and
suitable and able to meet the needs of children and families
served by the agency.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster care worker conducted a Zoom call with parent while
transporting children in vehicle.
Investigation
Relative Caregiver was interviewed via telephone on August
25, 2025. She stated Mother reported to her some Zoom calls
were occurring in the vehicle while transporting Youth A, Youth B
and Youth C and it seemed like some were done with Foster Care
Worker (FCW) while driving.
Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on
August 26, 2025. She stated the only Zoom call with Mother that
she is aware of involved 2 people while they were transporting
Youth A, Youth B and Youth C to a parenting time with Father.
FCW stated she was not involved with the Zoom call but stated
one individual was driving while the other individual handled the
phone. FCW didn’t know who completed the transport for visitation
in question. She stated several people within the agency transport
kids for visits.
Mother was interviewed via telephone on September 16, 2025.
She stated while she was in inpatient treatment there were a few
occasions when she had Zoom visits with her children. She stated
the Zoom calls occurred while her children were being transported
to parenting time with Father. She stated it did not involve FCW
and she can’t say for sure if the person holding the phone was the
same person who was driving.
Family Support Team Lead was interviewed via telephone on
September 16, 2025. She stated she mostly schedules parenting
time but also occasionally participates in parenting time. She
reported on the day of the particular parenting time she was
driving and Family Support worker was with her. During the
transport there was Zoom visit with Mother. She was driving and
Family Support worker was sitting in the back seat with the kids
facilitating the visit.
2

Family Support worker (FS worker) was interviewed via
telephone on October 9, 2025. She stated in early August 2025
she and Family Support Team Lead had picked up Youth A, Youth
B and Youth C and were transporting them to a parenting time
visit with their Father. During the trip, Family Support Team Lead
was driving and she was sitting in the back seat with the children.
During the car ride she conducted a Zoom call with Mother to
provide her with a Zoom visit since she was in treatment and not
able to participate in in-person visits at that time. Family Support
worker stated they didn’t continue with the Zoom visits moving
forward. Due to the children’s young age it was difficult to maintain
their attention.
Documents reviewed:
• MISACWIS case file. August 5, 2025, parenting time social
work contact states: “Children join the Zoom call in the car
via the Family Support worker’s phone during their
transport”.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. Based on completed
interviews there is no evidence to suggest FCW or any worker
from the agency conducted a Zoom call while transporting any of
the children.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement
Section • (3) The agency shall document all the following in the
Description child's record before a change of placement occurs:
• (a) Reason for the change in placement.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Foster child was moved from relative placement without
justification/explanation.
Investigation Relative Caregiver was interviewed via telephone on August
25, 2025. She stated Youth A was part of a sibling group of 7 that
were removed from parents on July 3, 2025. Youth A was placed
in her care, Youth B and Youth C were placed in a licensed foster
placement and the other four children were placed with their
respective non-respondent fathers. She stated she struggled from
the beginning with childcare and missed quite a bit of work
opportunities. Relative Caregiver stated she repeatedly asked the
agency for assistance, but they did nothing to help her. Relative
Caregiver ended up securing childcare on her own. She also
3

reported being concerned about the visitation schedule due to the
frequency and the distance the children would be transported.
Relative Caregiver stated one of the reasons Youth A was moved
was due to Relative Caregiver not supporting reunification. She
stated Father has done a lot of awful things to the children and
others. She doesn’t feel the kids are safe around him but
recognizes she doesn’t have the authority to prevent anything.
Relative Caregiver stated a Team Decision Meeting (TDM) took
place sometime toward the end of July 2025. She stated she
wasn’t aware of the purpose of the meeting as it wasn’t
communicated to her. During the TDM she stated all the
participants asked her to give up placement of Youth A. She
reported Youth A was doing well at that point. She was in daycare
and had an established bedtime routine. Relative Caregiver stated
two days later the same group called her and said they were
moving Youth A to a different placement. She verbalized she
didn’t agree to the placement change.
MDHHS Purchase of Services Foster Care worker (MDHHS
POS FCW) was interviewed via telephone on August 25, 2025.
She stated the case involves the removal of seven children. Four
of them were released to the care of their biological fathers, Youth
A was placed with Relative Caregiver and Youth B and Youth C
were placed in a licensed foster home.
MDHHS POS FCW clarified Youth A was placed with Relative
Caregiver at the time of removal. Relative Caregiver indicated she
was only able to provide placement with Youth A and not any of
the other children and had even questioned if she could care for
Youth A due to her work schedule and the need for childcare.
Relative Caregiver made several phone calls to multiple
individuals connected to the case such as Guardian ad Litem
(GAL), victim’s advocate associated with criminal case and staff at
Child & Family Services stating foster care is terrible, she’s
overwhelmed and no one is assisting her. When solutions were
offered she wasn’t willing to take it. For example, Relative
Caregiver made statements indicating no one is paying for
childcare. She was told the state will cover childcare expenses but
she needs to apply. She responded no one is helping her and they
need to apply for her. It was explained to her they are not able to
apply for her but they will bring a computer to her house to assist
her and she declined the offer.
4

Relative Caregiver also expressed not agreeing with parenting
time occurring. She verbalized that Father’s rights should be
terminated and questioned why visits were occurring.
Transportation for parenting time was provided by the agency.
Relative Caregiver complained about the number of people
picking up Youth A. MDHHS POS FCW stated she became a
barrier to reunification and there was concern it would continue to
get worse.
Relative Caregiver also was concerned about the expenses of
providing placement for Youth A. She was told she would get a
Determination of Care (DOC) and was provided approximately
$300 in gift cards.
A TDM was held to discuss the placement and concerns regarding
Relative Caregiver being overwhelmed. There was discussion
regarding the struggles she was having. At that point there was
not a decision made regarding placement but they wanted to get
Relative Caregiver’s thoughts. Relative Caregiver’s phone died
before the meeting concluded. The meeting continued for another
30 minutes and the placement decision was discussed without
Relative Caregiver. Another meeting was held the following day
with the Prosecuting Attorney to discuss the concerns. It was
decided to move forward with a placement change. MDHHS POS
FCW believes there were 3 meetings with GAL and Prosecuting
Attorney representing MDHHS to ensure the right decision was
made. MDHHS POS FCW stated reunifying 3 of the siblings by
moving Youth A into the licensed placement with Youth B and
Youth C who were already placed there also factored into the
decision. MDHHS POS FCW stated since Youth A was moved
there have been no concerns noted that she’s aware of.
Guardian ad Litem (GAL) was interviewed via telephone on
August 25, 2025. Youth A was removed from the parental home
on July 3, 2025. From the beginning, Relative Caregiver made
several statements that were not conducive to reunification. She
seemed to struggle understanding that even though some of the
things may have been occurring for a long time the court case just
started and there are expectations and requirements. Part of the
requirement is to provide parenting time. That was an issue from
day one because Relative Caregiver didn’t think Mother and
Father should be able to see the children at all. Complaints were
also made about the transportation to parenting time. A meeting
was scheduled to discuss placement preservation. During the
meeting every idea that was brought up to assist, Relative
Caregiver refused and said no she can’t do it. GAL stated Relative
5

Caregiver was almost begging for help but then would not take the
help when offered.
GAL stated a TDM was held to discuss the placement. During the
TDM everyone was trying to get a sense of what the issues were
and how they can assist. Relative Caregiver expressed concerns
regarding childcare and finances. MDHHS was able to assist with
childcare but caregiver needed to apply. It was offered to assist
her with the childcare application process but Relative Caregiver
refused. Anytime things came up and solutions were offered
Relative Caregiver would refuse or come up with a reason why it
wouldn’t work. She also complained about the number of
appointments and the number of individuals transporting Youth A
for parenting time. Due to the ongoing concerns with Relative
Caregiver and the ability to place Youth A in the same licensed
foster home with Youth B and Youth C, the decision was made to
change placement.
Foster Care Supervisor (FC supervisor) was interviewed via
telephone on August 26, 2025. Youth A was part of a sibling
group of 7 who were removed from parents on July 3, 2025. Youth
A was placed with Relative Caregiver and other placement
arrangements were found for the other children. FC supervisor
clarified the youngest 3 children are full siblings. Youth B and
Youth C were placed in a licensed foster home and the other
children were placed with their respective nonrespondent fathers.
Relative Caregiver expressed concern regarding finding childcare
and worried about being terminated from her job. FC supervisor
stated the agency offered to assist in applying and locating
childcare and Relative Caregiver would decline the assistance.
She ended up locating childcare that was almost an hour away
from her house and created another barrier due to distance and
time. There was also concern that Relative Caregiver was not on
board with reunification with Mother and Father. FC supervisor
stated Relative Caregiver made that known from the very
beginning. Her frustration was due to the number of CPS
complaints made before the children were eventually removed.
FC supervisor stated Relative Caregiver had notified the agency
toward the end of July 2025 she could not continue to provide
placement for Youth A due the distance between her home and
the day care and she felt she may end up losing her employment.
She had also stated Youth A wasn’t sleeping and it was disruptive
to her being able to sleep and maintain a healthy schedule. At that
point a TDM was scheduled for July 22, 2025. By the end of the
6

meeting, it was determined Youth A would be moved to the
licensed foster home where Youth B and Youth C were placed.
The individuals present for the TDM included Relative Caregiver
and a support person, GAL, MDHHS PAFC POS Monitor, FCW,
and FC supervisor. Everyone present, other than Relative
Caregiver felt it was in Youth A’s best interest long-term to be
moved to the placement of her full siblings.
Foster Care worker (FCW) was interviewed via telephone on
August 26, 2025. She stated Youth A was part of a sibling group
of 7 who were placed in foster care on July 3, 2025. Youth A was
placed with Relative Caregiver. FCW stated Relative Caregiver
contacted her on July 9, 2025 and other times afterward
requesting Youth A be moved. She stated she couldn’t maintain
placement any longer and expressed concern she would lose her
job and wasn’t able to find childcare. Relative Caregiver reported
being stressed and Youth A would cry all night. FCW stated she
assisted Relative Caregiver in applying for childcare. Relative
Caregiver located a childcare on her own but it was an hour away
from her home.
The first parenting time the children had Relative Caregiver made
a statement indicating she wasn’t in support of reunification and
didn’t think parents should be having any visitation. FCW stated
she had to explain the foster care process and the goal is
reunification and parenting time would be regularly scheduled.
Relative Caregiver expressed concerns regarding the visitation
schedule and would make it more difficult when it came to
scheduling the visits. FCW stated she would say it didn’t work with
the childcare provider or she would be vocal about the number of
people transporting Youth A to visits.
FCW stated a TDM was scheduled to discuss the concerns, and
the decision was made to move Youth A to the licensed foster
placement with Youth B and Youth C who are full siblings to her.
Relative Caregiver participated in the TDM and the concerns,
decision and reason for it was explained to her.
Foster Parent (FP) was interviewed via telephone on
September 16, 2025. She stated she had placement of Youth B
and Youth C since removal occurred on July 3, 2025. She stated
she was contacted by Child & Family Services about taking
placement of Youth A toward the end of July 2025. FP stated she
was told by the agency Relative Caregiver couldn’t handle
placement of Youth A any longer and they were looking to place
Youth A with her full siblings as well. FP clarified she has a
7

personal relationship with Relative Caregiver, and she had never
made those comments to her. FP stated Relative Caregiver
reported she wanted more support trying to locate childcare.
Mother was interviewed via telephone on September 16, 2025.
Mother stated Youth A was moved from Relative Caregiver while
she was in inpatient treatment. She stated she was not provided
any explanation as far as why Youth A was moved from Relative
Caregiver at the time the placement change occurred but has
since been told the reason is so Youth A, Youth B and Youth C
can be in the same home. She stated FCW informed her she
would be notified if there were any changes with her case or
anything impacting her children and their placement. She was not
told about the placement change at the time it occurred. She
stated she was in treatment at the time but had signed the
necessary releases of information that allowed FCW to contact
her while she was there.
Documents reviewed:
• MISACWIS case file. Social work contacts in July 2025
verify Relative Caregiver requested assistance with
childcare. Relative Caregiver made statements indicating
she needs to give up Youth A due to not locating childcare.
FCW conducted a home visit and assisted with completion
of childcare assistance application.
• July 22, 2025, Team Decision Meeting. Relative Caregiver
cited numerous frustrations including difficulty with Youth
A’s needs, specifically at bedtime, multiple agency staff
transporting Youth A to parenting time visits, Mother and
Father allowed to participate in parenting time, number of
Youth A’s appointments and the distance from her home to
Youth A’s daycare. The agency is recommending
replacement of Youth A to a home that is able to address
her needs. The agency will attempt to secure a placement
that is able to take Youth A along with Youth B and Youth
C.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of MISACWIS case file the agency made
the decision to move Youth A to a licensed placement for valid
reasons that were documented and communicated. The decision
was made with the input of relevant parties including GAL,
Prosecuting Attorney and MDHHS POS FCW.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
8

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
